sentence-detokenized: The EU rejects Germany's call for a boycott of British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday it disagreed with Germany's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists determine whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Germany's representative on the European Union's veterinary committee, Werner Zwingmann, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheep meat from countries other than Britain until scientific recommendations are clearer.
"We do not support any such recommendation because we do not see any reasons for it," said Nikolaus van der Pas, the Commission's chief spokesman, at a press briefing.
He said that further scientific study is needed and if it is found that action is needed, the European Union should take it.

EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler's proposal last month to ban sheep brains, spleens and spinal cords in the human and animal food chain is a very specific and preventive step to protect human health, he said.
Fischler proposed the pan-European measures after reports came from Britain and France that sheep could contract bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) - mad cow disease - in laboratory conditions.

However, Fischler agreed to reconsider his proposal after the EU Standing Veterinary Committee and national veterinary officials questioned the justification for such a measure, saying there was little risk to human health.
Earlier, at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers, Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio accused Fischler of raising unfounded alarm by "dangerous generalisations".
Only France and the UK supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU's Scientific Veterinary and Multidisciplinary Committees are due to re-examine the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
It has long been known that sheep can become infected with scrapie, a BSE-like brain-damaging disease that is likely to have been transmitted to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers denied on Thursday that their sheep posed any danger to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"We need to be very careful how other countries take up the example of Germany," John Lloyd Jones, president of the Welsh National Farmers Union (NFU), told BBC radio.

Bonn led the effort to protect public health after consumer confidence collapsed in March after a British report suggested people could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease by eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47 600 sheep from Britain last year, almost half of the total.
It imported 4 275 tonnes of British sheepmeat, representing around 10% of total imports.
A rare cover of a Hendrix song sells for nearly $17,000.
A rare handwritten sketch of a song by American guitar legend Jimi Hendrix was auctioned for nearly $17,000 on Thursday at an auction of the late musician's favourite things.
A Florida restaurant paid £10,925 ($16,935) for a draft of "Ain't No Telling," which Hendrix wrote on paper in a London hotel in late 1966.
At the end of a concert in Nottingham, England, in January 1967, he threw a piece of paper into the audience, where it was retrieved by a fan.
Buyers were also interested in 16 other items offered for auction by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him from 1966-1969.
It included a black lacquered and mother-of-pearl inlaid box that Hendrix used to store his drugs, which an anonymous Australian buyer purchased for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died in 1970 at the age of 27 from a drug overdose.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the atmosphere for talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China on Thursday accused Taipei of spoiling the atmosphere for renewed cross-Strait talks with Taiwanese Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Ukraine this week, which infuriated Beijing.

Just hours after Chinese state media said it was time to start political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Kuofang told Reuters, "Taiwanese authorities have disrupted the atmosphere necessary to start talks. "
State media quoted China's chief negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubei, as telling a group of guests from Taiwan on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"Now is the time for both sides to begin political talks...
is to end the state of hostility," Tang was quoted as saying in Thursday's overseas edition of the People's Daily.

In an interview with Reuters television, Shen of the Foreign Ministry said he had read reports of Tang's comments but gave no details on why the negotiator considered it time to talk with Taiwan, which Beijing considers a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed all of Taipei's efforts to gain greater international recognition, was angered this week by Taiwanese Vice President Lien's visit to Ukraine.
China says the time has come for negotiations on Taiwan.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China has said that the time has come for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps to achieve that goal.

Late on Wednesday evening, the official Xinhua News Agency quoted Tang Shubei, executive vice chairman of the Cross-Strait Relations Association, as saying that consultations would be held to determine the time and format of the talks.
German car registrations in July rose 14.2 pct y/y.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22

The number of motor vehicles registered for the first time in Germany rose by 14.2% in July this year compared to the previous year, according to figures released on Thursday by the Federal Motor Vehicle Authority.
The Bureau reported that 356,725 new cars were registered in July 1996 - 304,850 cars and 15,613 trucks.
These figures represent a 13.6% increase for cars and a 2.2% decrease for trucks compared to July 1995.
Motorcycle registrations increased by 32.7% during this period.
According to the Federal Office, the growth was partly due to an increased number of Germans buying German cars abroad, while domestic demand is weak, according to manufacturers.
Almost all German car manufacturers recorded an increase in registrations during the period.
Volkswagen AG received 77,719 registrations, slightly more than a quarter of the total.
Opel AG and General Motors came second with 49,269 registrations, 16.4% of the total.
In third place was Ford with 35,563 registrations, or 11.7%.
Only Seat and Porsche recorded fewer registrations in July 1996 compared to last July.
Seat recorded 3,420 registrations compared to 5,522 in July a year ago.
The number of Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554.
THE GREEK SOCIALISTS HAVE GIVEN THE PRIME MINISTER THE GREEN LIGHT FOR ELECTIONS.
The executive board of the Greek Socialist Party has given the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to call early elections, party secretary-general Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official statement after a cabinet meeting later on Thursday, Skandalidis said.

Port conditions from Lloyds Shipping Intelligence Service --
LATTAKIA, 10 August - The waiting time in Lattakia and Tartous is currently 24 hours.
Israel downplays fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries appeared like a storm in a glass of water.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador in Washington led the failed negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that it seems Damascus wants to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that {(1)[MISC's] Syrian priority} is still negotiation.
The Syrians are confused, they're definitely tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that this is basically a storm in a glass of water," he said.
Rabinovic ends his tenure as ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, a former Israeli envoy to Egypt and politician from the right-wing Likud party.
Israel sent a message to Syria through Washington on Wednesday that it is committed to peace and wants to start negotiations without preconditions.
But she warned Damascus that it was creating a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria on Wednesday accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently test-fired a missile.
It stated that its arms purchases were for defensive purposes.

"The message we have sent (to Syrian President Hafiz al-Assad) is that Israel is ready to start peace talks at any time without preconditions," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview with Israel Radio.
Tensions have been escalating since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June, when he promised to keep the Golan Heights, which Israel won from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
The Israeli-Syrian peace talks on the Golan stalled as early as 1991, despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions on the Golan.
Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February.
"The voices coming from Damascus are bad, not good.
The media...
are full of expressions and statements that must be disturbing...
this artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its captives," Levy said.
"We expect Syria, if it is peaceful, to respond to Israel's message to start peace negotiations, because that is our goal," he said. "
We don't want war, God forbid.
Wars do no one any good. "
Israel's Channel Two television said Damascus had sent a "reassuring signal" to Israel.
She did not cite any source for the report.
Spokesmen for Netanyahu and Levy said they could not confirm that.
The television station also said Netanyahu sent messages to reassure Syria through Cairo, the United States and Moscow.
A Polish diplomat denies that nurses are stranded in Libya.

A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a Polish tabloid report this week that Libya had refused to grant exit visas to 100 Polish nurses who wanted to return home after working in the North African country.
"That's not true.

To date, we are not aware that she has been stranded in Libya or held without her will, and we have not received any complaints," Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, charge d'affaires at the Polish embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by telephone.

Poland's labour ministry said this week it would send an investigation team to Libya, but Awdankiewicz said the investigation was prompted by complaints from some nurses about their working conditions, such as non-payment of wages.
He said there were an estimated 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iranian exile group based in Iraq pledged Thursday to support Iranian Kurdish rebels after they were attacked by Iranian forces deep inside Iraq last month.

A statement from the Mujahideen Khalq said their leader, Massoud Rajavi, met with Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI) Secretary General Hassan Rastegar in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed support for the Iranian rebel Kurds.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian resistance will continue to stand by its Kurdish compatriots and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan," he said.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "signals a new level of cooperation between the Mujahideen Khalq and the Iranian Kurdish opposition".
In July, Iran intensively bombed targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of KDPI militants located in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside the control of the government in Baghdad.
Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are under the control of militants of the Iraqi Kurdish group Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK).
The PUK and the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), Iraq's two main Kurdish factions, have controlled northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were driven out of Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Clashes between the two sides erupted over the weekend in the most serious fighting since the US-sponsored ceasefire last year.
The Mujahideen Khalq said Iranian forces had also shelled KDP positions in the Qasri area of Suleimaniyah province near the Iranian border over the past two days.
It said about 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey are launching air and ground strikes on targets in northern Iraq to pursue their Kurdish rebels.
US-led air forces in southern Turkey protect Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by Baghdad forces.
Saudi riyal stable in quiet summer trading.
The spot Saudi riyal against the dollar and interbank riyal deposit rates were mostly stable this week in quiet summer trading, traders in the kingdom said.
"There have been no changes in the Saudi riyal rates.
The market was very quiet because of the summer holidays," said one trader.
The spot rate for the riyal was set at 3.7504 / 06 per dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were at 5-1/2, 3/8%, three-month at 5-5/8, 1/2% and six-month at 5-3/4, 5/8%.
One-year funds were at 6, 5-7/8 percent.
Israel approves Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Israel on Thursday allowed Palestinian President Yasser Arafat to fly over its territory into the West Bank, ending a brief crisis between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organisation, an Arafat aide said.
"The problem is over.
The president's plane has been cleared to fly through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to leave for the West Bank before Monday," Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Thursday, but the venue was changed to Gaza after Israel refused to allow the Palestinian leader's helicopter to fly.
Palestinian officials have accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to prevent the Ramallah meeting by keeping Arafat on his toes.
Arafat subsequently cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials on civilian affairs at the Allenby Bridge between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday after Israel lifted the ban because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat meets Peres in Gaza after the flight ban.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after Palestinians said the right-wing Israeli government banned the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank to hold talks with the former prime minister.

Japanese Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said at a press conference on Wednesday that in his view the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy, which is aimed at ensuring economic growth, has not changed following the publication of the central bank's "tankan" survey.
